news_summary: Advancements in organ transplant techniques and innovative non-medication therapies are improving patient outcomes, while ongoing efforts address public health challenges and promote ethical standards in medical research.
news_summary_fr: Les progrès des techniques de transplantation d'organes et les thérapies non médicamenteuses innovantes améliorent les résultats pour les patients, tandis que des efforts continus sont déployés pour relever les défis en matière de santé publique et promouvoir des normes éthiques dans le domaine de la recherche médicale.
news_summary_es: Los avances en las técnicas de trasplante de órganos y las terapias innovadoras sin medicamentos están mejorando los resultados de los pacientes, al tiempo que los esfuerzos en curso abordan los retos de la salud pública y promueven normas éticas en la investigación médica.

articles.title: Heart from organ donor restarted outside the body — technique offers new source of organs
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 17 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02243-0Current procedures for reviving a heart for transplant are ethically fraught or expensive.
articles.content:
New methods to revive and preserve donor hearts could increase the number of organs available for transplant.Credit: Lennart Nilsson, TT/Science Photo Library

Surgeons have developed two low-cost techniques to revive the hearts of people who wish to donate their organs after they die. The methods have only been tested on a small number of people, but they avoid ethical issues sometimes associated with current transplantation techniques.

Using one of the techniques1, surgeons received permission to remove the heart of a child who had been declared dead, restart it and transplant it into another child. The technique, described in the New England Journal of Medicine (NEJM) today, could increase the number of hearts available for organ donation, particularly for children. Roughly 500 children per year in the United States get a new heart, but many will die while waiting for one.

In the second technique, also reported in the NEJM today2, researchers were able to freeze-preserve adult hearts inside the bodies of their donors, then transplant them successfully. The surgeons involved say this procedure could also be used in children.

“These two techniques represent important new advances” in procuring hearts from some donors because they sidestep the ethical challenges of existing methods, says Robert Montgomery, a transplant surgeon at New York University (NYU) in New York City.

Current challenges

Most donated hearts come from people who have been declared brain dead but whose heart is still beating. However, there are not enough such cases to meet the demand for donor hearts.

In some cases, hearts can be obtained from donors who are declared dead once their heart has stopped beating for five minutes — for example when a family decides to remove life support for an individual.

For these hearts to be suitable for transplantation, surgeons must typically either remove the organ from the body and restart it on a machine or get it to beat again while still inside the body. But the former option is expensive and can’t be used for donors weighing less than 40 kilograms, which excludes babies and most children, and the latter is not widely used because of potential ethical issues.

The main ethical concern raised by physicians is that jumpstarting the heart while it is still in the body might require a change to the recorded cause of death, from circulatory death to brain death. Another issue is that the procedure could theoretically restore blood flow to the brain — although clamps are used to block this outcome.

Reviving tiny hearts

To avoid these potential issues, Joseph Turek, a paediatric cardiac surgeon at Duke University in Durham, North Carolina, and his colleagues developed a system to revive children’s hearts outside the body1. This involves pumping oxygenated blood into the heart through a tube attached to the aorta. The blood is then drained out of the heart through a vent in the left ventricle, collected in a bag to be re-oxygenated then pumped back into the heart.

The team tested the procedure in 12-week-old piglets before the first human trial earlier this year. In that case, surgeons removed the heart of a one-month-old baby who had died, restarted it outside their body then transplanted it into a three-month old baby.

Three months later, the recipient’s heart continued to function normally with no signs of rejection, according to the NEJM report. The procedure could result in 100 more paediatric heart transplants a year in the United States, says Turek. It also offers a cost-effective alternative to out-of-body revival of adult hearts, he adds, because it doesn’t require equipment that can cost tens of thousands of dollars.
articles.reasoning: This article reports on innovative medical techniques that revive donor hearts outside the body, potentially increasing the availability of organs for transplantation, especially for children. The advances address ethical concerns and cost issues, offering hope to many patients on waiting lists.
articles.personality_title: New technique revives donor hearts outside the body, boosting transplant hope
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
There is a big need for donated hearts to help people who need transplants. But current ways to bring hearts back to life for transplant are often costly or raise ethical questions.

**What happened**
Doctors created two affordable methods to restart hearts from donors after death, outside the body. These have been tested on a small group and avoid some ethical problems linked to older methods.

**Impact**
These new techniques could increase the number of hearts available for transplant, especially helping children in need. They offer a promising, cheaper, and ethically clearer way to save more lives.

**What's next step**
Researchers will work on testing these methods further with more donors to confirm safety and effectiveness, aiming to make this approach standard in hospitals.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Innovative, low-cost heart revival methods could transform organ donation and save many more lives.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle technique relance les cœurs de donneurs hors du corps, offrant un nouvel espoir
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Le besoin de cœurs donnés pour les transplantations est important. Mais les méthodes actuelles pour redonner vie aux cœurs sont souvent coûteuses ou soulèvent des questions éthiques.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Des médecins ont développé deux techniques abordables pour relancer des cœurs de donneurs après la mort, hors du corps. Ces méthodes ont été testées sur un petit groupe et évitent certains problèmes éthiques des méthodes anciennes.

**Impact**
Ces techniques pourraient augmenter le nombre de cœurs disponibles, aidant particulièrement les enfants. Elles promettent une manière moins chère et plus claire sur le plan éthique de sauver plus de vies.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs prévoient de tester ces méthodes sur davantage de donneurs pour confirmer leur sécurité et leur efficacité, avec l'objectif de les généraliser dans les hôpitaux.

**Une phrase à retenir**
Des méthodes innovantes et peu coûteuses pour relancer les cœurs pourraient transformer le don d'organes et sauver beaucoup plus de vies.
articles.personality_title_es: Nueva técnica revive corazones de donantes fuera del cuerpo, aumentando la esperanza de trasplante
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Hay una gran necesidad de corazones donados para ayudar a quienes necesitan trasplantes. Pero las formas actuales de reanimar corazones para trasplante suelen ser costosas o plantean dudas éticas.

**Qué pasó**
Los médicos desarrollaron dos métodos asequibles para reiniciar corazones de donantes tras la muerte, fuera del cuerpo. Estos se probaron en un pequeño grupo y evitan algunos problemas éticos de métodos antiguos.

**Impacto**
Estas nuevas técnicas podrían aumentar la cantidad de corazones disponibles, ayudando especialmente a niños. Ofrecen una forma más económica y ética de salvar más vidas.

**Próximo paso**
Los investigadores seguirán probando estos métodos con más donantes para confirmar su seguridad y eficacia, con la meta de que se conviertan en práctica habitual en hospitales.

**Una frase para recordar**
Métodos innovadores y económicos para revivir corazones pueden transformar la donación de órganos y salvar muchas más vidas.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of two stylized, gently glowing hearts—one small and one larger—connected by a delicate, flowing tube through which a soft stream of light pulses, set against a calm, neutral background with subtle hints of soft reds and blues, symbolizing the revival and life-giving connection of donor hearts outside the body without showing any human figures.

articles.title: Doctors used music instead of medication—what they saw in dementia patients was remarkable
articles.summary: A groundbreaking pilot in NHS dementia wards is using live music therapy—called MELODIC—to ease patient distress without relying on drugs. Developed by researchers and clinicians with input from patients and families, this low-cost approach embeds music therapists directly into care teams. Early results show improved patient wellbeing and less disruptive behavior, sparking hope for wider NHS adoption.
articles.content:
A new treatment that uses music therapy on dementia wards could improve care and support for some of the NHS's most vulnerable patients.

Researchers at Anglia Ruskin University (ARU) and Cambridgeshire and Peterborough NHS Foundation Trust have piloted a music therapy approach called MELODIC, across two NHS dementia wards.

More alternatives to psychotropic medication are needed to support dementia patients who experience severe distress.

The pilot study involved a music therapist being embedded on hospital wards, the delivery of clinical music sessions and the implementation of musical care plans for each patient, and results from the research have now been published in the journal Frontiers in Psychiatry.

Music therapy, delivered by trained therapists, can include singing, playing or listening to music. The therapist can also identify specific ways that music can be used by families and carers in an individual's daily care routine.

During the study, patient data suggested a slight improvement in quality-of-life scores among patients and a reduction in the severity of distress symptoms and disruptiveness, although agitation scores increased slightly.

There were no increases in routinely reported incidents, and no adverse events related to music therapy interventions were reported. This is relevant for future research on mental health dementia wards where limited studies have been conducted to date.

Lead author Naomi Thompson, a researcher at the Cambridge Institute for Music Therapy Research at Anglia Ruskin University (ARU), said: "People with dementia on inpatient mental health wards are often experiencing very high levels of distress, and staff are under immense pressure to manage this in ways that are safe and compassionate.

"Our study yielded promising results and importantly showed that the MELODIC tool can be used effectively in these highly complex settings, giving an alternative option to current ways of managing severe distress, such as psychotropic medication."

The approach was shaped by interviews with 49 healthcare professionals, patients, and their families about their experiences managing distress on dementia wards and using music in everyday care and life to help develop the intervention, with findings published in the Journal of Geriatric Psychiatry.

Importantly, the intervention -- which has been co-designed by clinicians, researchers, and people with lived experience - cost just £2,025 per month for the therapist and £400 initial outlay for equipment, suggesting a low-cost, scalable model.

Dr Ben Underwood, Research and Development Director and Honorary Consultant Psychiatrist at CPFT said: "Some people with dementia can get so confused and distressed that we need to admit them to hospital to keep them safe. It can be difficult to manage distress in a ward environment and hard for patients, families and staff.

"I am very excited that it may now be possible for NHS staff to improve their experience on dementia wards using the power of music, and we look forward to working with ARU to develop this further."

The current study was funded by the National Institute for Health and Care Research (NIHR), and is published in the journal Frontiers in Psychiatry.
articles.reasoning: This article reports on a promising, low-cost music therapy intervention that improves wellbeing and reduces distress in dementia patients without relying on medication. It highlights scientific and medical advances, compassionate care, and potential for wider NHS adoption, which is likely to inspire hope and positivity among a broad audience.
articles.personality_title: Music therapy brings hope and calm to dementia patients in NHS wards
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Dementia patients often face distress and agitation, and many wards rely on medications that can have side effects. Finding gentler, more natural ways to help these patients has been a challenge for the NHS.

**What happened**
Researchers and clinicians at Anglia Ruskin University and local NHS trusts introduced a new approach called MELODIC, where live music therapists join dementia ward teams. Instead of medication, these therapists use music to soothe and engage patients, helping reduce their distress.

**Impact**
Early results from this pilot show that patients feel calmer and more comfortable, with fewer disruptive behaviors. This low-cost method also supports staff by offering a fresh, compassionate way to improve patient care.

**What's next step**
With promising outcomes, there’s hope the NHS will adopt MELODIC more widely, bringing music therapy to more dementia wards across the country.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Using live music therapy in dementia care offers a hopeful, drug-free way to improve patient wellbeing and reduce distress.
articles.personality_title_fr: La musicothérapie apporte espoir et apaisement aux patients atteints de démence dans les services du NHS
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les patients atteints de démence souffrent souvent de détresse et d’agitation, et de nombreux services utilisent des médicaments pouvant avoir des effets secondaires. Trouver des moyens plus doux et naturels pour aider ces patients est un défi pour le NHS.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Des chercheurs et cliniciens de l’université Anglia Ruskin et des trusts locaux du NHS ont introduit une nouvelle approche appelée MELODIC, où des musicothérapeutes en direct font partie des équipes des services de démence. Au lieu de médicaments, ces thérapeutes utilisent la musique pour apaiser et engager les patients, aidant à réduire leur détresse.

**Impact**
Les premiers résultats de ce projet pilote montrent que les patients se sentent plus calmes et à l’aise, avec moins de comportements perturbateurs. Cette méthode peu coûteuse soutient aussi le personnel en offrant une manière nouvelle et bienveillante d’améliorer les soins.

**La prochaine étape**
Avec ces résultats prometteurs, on espère que le NHS adoptera MELODIC plus largement, apportant la musicothérapie à davantage de services pour patients atteints de démence à travers le pays.

**En une phrase**
Utiliser la musicothérapie en direct dans les soins de la démence offre une manière pleine d’espoir et sans médicament d’améliorer le bien-être des patients et de réduire leur détresse.
articles.personality_title_es: La musicoterapia trae esperanza y calma a pacientes con demencia en los servicios del NHS
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los pacientes con demencia a menudo enfrentan angustia y agitación, y muchas salas dependen de medicamentos que pueden tener efectos secundarios. Encontrar formas más suaves y naturales de ayudar a estos pacientes ha sido un desafío para el NHS.

**Qué pasó**
Investigadores y clínicos de la Universidad Anglia Ruskin y de trusts locales del NHS introdujeron un nuevo enfoque llamado MELODIC, donde terapeutas de música en vivo se integran en los equipos de las salas de demencia. En lugar de medicamentos, estos terapeutas usan la música para calmar e involucrar a los pacientes, ayudando a reducir su angustia.

**Impacto**
Los primeros resultados de este piloto muestran que los pacientes se sienten más tranquilos y cómodos, con menos comportamientos disruptivos. Este método de bajo costo también apoya al personal, ofreciendo una forma nueva y compasiva de mejorar la atención al paciente.

**Próximo paso**
Con resultados prometedores, se espera que el NHS adopte MELODIC de manera más amplia, llevando la musicoterapia a más salas de demencia en todo el país.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Usar la musicoterapia en vivo en el cuidado de la demencia ofrece una forma esperanzadora y sin drogas de mejorar el bienestar del paciente y reducir la angustia.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a cozy hospital room softly lit, featuring a gently glowing music note-shaped light above a comfortable armchair beside a small vintage radio and a sheet of music resting on a table; nearby, an abstract, translucent silhouette of a calm elderly figure with subtle, colorful sound waves flowing around them, symbolizing the healing power of music therapy on dementia wards, using soft natural tones of blues, warm browns, and gentle creams.

articles.title: Dirty water, warm trucks, and the real reason romaine keeps making us sick
articles.summary: Romaine lettuce has a long history of E. coli outbreaks, but scientists are zeroing in on why. A new study reveals that the way lettuce is irrigated—and how it’s kept cool afterward—can make all the difference. Spraying leaves with untreated surface water is a major risk factor, while switching to drip or furrow irrigation cuts contamination dramatically. Add in better cold storage from harvest to delivery, and the odds of an outbreak plummet. The research offers a clear, science-backed path to safer salads—one that combines smarter farming with better logistics.
articles.content:
E. coli outbreaks in romaine lettuce have long been a public health concern. and now a new Cornell University paper suggests that a combination of efforts in the field, and even postharvest techniques, can minimize risk to human health.

Co-authored by Renata Ivanek, a professor in the department of population medicine and diagnostic sciences, and Martin Wiedmann, professor in food safety, the paper outlines interventions likely to make a concrete difference in the safety of the nation's romaine.

"This study supports that interventions should focus on reducing produce contamination via contaminated irrigation water, on assuring that produce washes applied during processing consistently deliver reasonably high reductions of bacterial numbers, and on improving temperature control during distribution," Wiedmann said.

"We tried to describe the system as holistically as possible to account for different risk factors and how they could have interactions," Ivanek said. "There's not just one intervention that will save us all. We spent a lot of time trying to understand the preharvest component, especially the irrigation water piece and how much risk can be explained by that."

Study results suggested that much contamination originates from irrigation with untreated surface water applied through overhead spray irrigation systems. They found that risk from irrigation was reduced either through water treatments or by switching to furrow or drip irrigation.

"While not the most common system, spray irrigation is used in a number of fields for its benefits during germination, its cooling effect on plants and other reasons. But drip or furrow irrigation reduces the probability that water directly touches the leaves," Ivanek said, acknowledging that switching to these other irrigation systems introduces significant potential additional costs to grower.

Ivanek and her co-authors also explored the importance of maintaining proper cold storage temperatures along the entire supply chain to romaine's final destination.

"Time and temperature play a role in food safety, and also in food quality and shelf life," she said, describing a "perfect storm" if contamination happens at the farm or processing level and then improper transportation temperatures allow bacteria to grow.

The comprehensive practices and interventions explored in this study intend to aid decision-makers in establishing and enhancing food safety best management practices, Ivanek said.

"The big message is the American food supply chain is extremely safe compared to other countries," she said. "We're exploring how can we make it even safer and where we should put additional effort."
articles.reasoning: The article presents scientific research identifying practical interventions to reduce E. coli contamination in romaine lettuce, which is a significant public health concern. The study offers clear, actionable solutions that can make food safer, thus protecting consumers and improving overall food safety.
articles.personality_title: New study reveals simple ways to keep romaine lettuce safe from E. coli
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Romaine lettuce has often been linked to outbreaks of E. coli, a harmful bacteria that can make people very sick. Scientists have been searching for the reasons behind these outbreaks to protect public health.

**What happened**
Researchers at Cornell University studied how romaine lettuce is grown and handled. They discovered that spraying untreated surface water on lettuce leaves is a major way E. coli spreads. By switching irrigation methods to drip or furrow systems—which deliver water directly to the soil instead of the leaves—contamination drops sharply. They also found that keeping lettuce cold from harvest through delivery greatly reduces bacteria growth.

**Impact**
These findings offer a clear, science-backed way to make our salads safer. Farmers and distributors can use smarter watering techniques and better cold storage to lower the risk of E. coli outbreaks, protecting consumers from illness.

**What's next step**
The next challenge is encouraging more farmers and suppliers to adopt these safer practices. Sharing this knowledge and supporting improvements in irrigation and refrigeration can help prevent future outbreaks and keep romaine lettuce safe for everyone.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Simple changes in watering and cold storage can dramatically reduce E. coli contamination in romaine lettuce, making our salads safer to enjoy.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle étude révèle comment garder la laitue romaine sûre contre E. coli
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
La laitue romaine est souvent liée à des épidémies d'E. coli, une bactérie dangereuse qui peut rendre les gens très malades. Les scientifiques cherchent les causes pour protéger la santé publique.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Des chercheurs de l'Université Cornell ont étudié la culture et la manipulation de la laitue romaine. Ils ont découvert que pulvériser de l'eau de surface non traitée sur les feuilles est une source majeure d'E. coli. En changeant pour des systèmes d'irrigation goutte à goutte ou en rigole—qui apportent l'eau directement au sol plutôt qu'aux feuilles—la contamination diminue fortement. Ils ont aussi noté que garder la laitue au frais de la récolte à la livraison réduit beaucoup la croissance des bactéries.

**Impact**
Ces résultats offrent une méthode claire et scientifique pour rendre nos salades plus sûres. Les agriculteurs et distributeurs peuvent utiliser des techniques d'arrosage plus intelligentes et un meilleur stockage au froid pour réduire les risques, protégeant ainsi les consommateurs.

**Prochaine étape**
Le prochain défi est d'encourager plus d'agriculteurs et fournisseurs à adopter ces pratiques plus sûres. Partager ces connaissances et soutenir l'amélioration de l'irrigation et de la réfrigération peut aider à prévenir les futures épidémies.

**Phrase clé**
Des changements simples dans l'arrosage et le stockage au froid peuvent réduire considérablement la contamination par E. coli dans la laitue romaine, rendant nos salades plus sûres.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevo estudio revela formas sencillas de mantener segura la lechuga romana contra E. coli
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
La lechuga romana ha estado relacionada con brotes de E. coli, una bacteria peligrosa que puede enfermar gravemente a las personas. Los científicos han buscado las causas para proteger la salud pública.

**Qué pasó**
Investigadores de la Universidad de Cornell estudiaron cómo se cultiva y maneja la lechuga romana. Descubrieron que rociar agua de superficie sin tratar sobre las hojas es una vía importante para la propagación de E. coli. Al cambiar a métodos de riego por goteo o surcos, que llevan el agua directamente al suelo y no a las hojas, la contaminación baja mucho. También encontraron que mantener la lechuga fría desde la cosecha hasta la entrega reduce mucho el crecimiento de bacterias.

**Impacto**
Estos hallazgos ofrecen una manera clara y respaldada por la ciencia para hacer nuestras ensaladas más seguras. Agricultores y distribuidores pueden usar técnicas de riego más inteligentes y mejor almacenamiento en frío para reducir el riesgo de brotes, protegiendo a los consumidores.

**Próximo paso**
El siguiente reto es motivar a más agricultores y proveedores a adoptar estas prácticas más seguras. Compartir este conocimiento y apoyar mejoras en riego y refrigeración puede ayudar a prevenir futuros brotes y mantener segura la lechuga romana.

**Mensaje en una frase**
Cambios simples en el riego y el almacenamiento en frío pueden reducir drásticamente la contaminación por E. coli en la lechuga romana, haciendo nuestras ensaladas más seguras para disfrutar.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a lush romaine lettuce field with clean, gentle drip irrigation lines watering vibrant green leaves, alongside a rustic farm truck carrying crates of fresh lettuce through a cool, misty morning landscape, all rendered in soft, natural earth tones and greens without human figures.

articles.title: Should I tell anyone that I suspect misconduct in a paper I’m reviewing?
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 18 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-01954-8A cancer researcher is suspicious about a paper they’ve been asked to review. What steps should they take?
articles.content:
Illustration: David Parkins

The problem Dear Nature, I work in an oncology laboratory in the United States. After being asked to review a paper, I noticed that in one of the main figures, several images appeared identical to those of a previous publication I had read. I empathize with how difficult assembling papers can be, and I understand that unintentional errors can be introduced. Accusing authors of misconduct can have significant professional, social and (potentially) legal ramifications. Even worse, it can alert authors to cover their tracks if actual misconduct did occur. Who do I tell and what should I say? Is there anything that we, as reviewers, should ask to give authors a chance to respond that is respectful, but that also ensures sound work? – A wary oncology researcher

The advice

Paper retractions are growing, along with awareness of the problem of scientific misconduct. From plagiarism, to text generated by artificial intelligence, to authorship for sale, many papers are being submitted to journals in bad faith. If those papers are then published, this can weaken research fields and potentially have tragic consequences if, for instance, oncologists rely on unreliable research when treating people with cancer.

But part of the review process is checking for mistakes made in good faith, too. Not all papers that are flagged are actually fraudulent. As you suggest, errors can creep into papers even when the authors did not intend to take shortcuts. Unfounded accusations can prevent the publication of important research, damage careers and potentially have blowback for the critic.

Peer reviewers play a crucial part, together with journal editors and publishers, in helping to ensure the quality and credibility of published journal articles. But a lack of time and review guidance can limit reviewers’ ability to raise concerns.

An ‘agony aunt’ for working scientists

Nature reached out to three researchers who have navigated this delicate terrain.

Extend the benefit of the doubt

There might be a reasonable explanation for the images’ similarities. Jennifer Byrne, an oncology researcher at the University of Sydney, Australia, suggests checking for two things. First, do the images in the earlier paper relate to the same things (proteins and cell lines, for example) that are described in the later paper? (You can also consider annotations around the image, such as whether new descriptions been added.) Second, do the two papers have authors in common? If both conditions are met, the authors could be reusing their previous data. This might be justifiable or an honest mistake, says Byrne, who also researches scientific integrity.

Even if the authorship teams are different, there might be good reason for reusing the images. “Some images can be provided by repositories as data to be reused for different research questions,” Byrne explains. Or the submitting authors might have obtained permission from the copyright holders to reuse images from a previous study, for comparison purposes. In any case, Byrne says, “any intentional image reuse should nonetheless be clearly described in the manuscript”. It should therefore also be cited in the references, following almost all publishers’ guidelines.

These kinds of concern should be mentioned in the reviewers’ comments to the authors. However, Byrne says that it could be more worrying if the images in the paper under review refer to things other than those in the published paper.

Apart from apparently duplicated images, a reviewer might pick up on other issues in a submitted manuscript. For instance, Brian Jones, a biologist at Murdoch University in Perth, Australia, checks a selection of references to ensure that they back up the statements being made by the submission. Again, divergence could be an honest mistake by an author in a rush. Or it could be a sign of citation manipulation, in which irrelevant references are deliberately inserted into a paper to boost citation scores.

Talk to the editor

Issues should be raised confidentially with the editor of the journal, for instance by e-mailing the handling editor or using the ‘contact the editor’ feature in online submission systems. “It’s important to recognize that manuscripts are provided to reviewers on a confidential basis, so reviewers should not communicate concerns to anyone outside the peer-review process,” Byrne emphasizes.

This communication should include the evidence you’ve gathered, including a link to the previous publication and the figure numbers that seem to be duplicated, says Jillian Goldfarb, an engineering researcher at Cornell University in Ithaca, New York. In this first alert to the editor, she recommends that you “ask for guidance as to whether or not you should continue to review the paper, or if they would like to pause the review process to investigate the matter”.

Check your tone

Whether in communications with the editor or in comments for the authors, it’s risky to suggest that wrongdoing has been committed. Goldfarb has seen first-hand the political complexities of publishing. In 2023, she resigned as a journal editor, partly because of ethical concerns about suspicious papers.

The advice-givers emphasize that, to avoid legal action, it’s not a good idea to use words such as ‘fraud’. Instead, it’s best to express concisely and objectively the reasons for concern. “Where you will get into trouble is if you suggest that the errors were deliberate,” Jones cautions. Rather than mentioning plagiarism, for instance, he suggests writing something along the lines of “paragraph 6 appears to be identical to that in the paper by XXX”. For detailed legal advice, however, you should contact a professional.

This advice applies even in seemingly blatant cases of misconduct. Jones gives the example of a submitted paper that included an author who had died five years previously. Still, he covered his bases: “I checked the e-mail in that case, and the institute confirmed the death and expressed a lack of knowledge of the paper, so it wasn’t a posthumous submission.”
articles.reasoning: The article addresses the important role of peer reviewers in maintaining scientific integrity, particularly in cancer research, which ultimately supports trustworthy medical advances and patient safety. While it discusses concerns about potential misconduct, the focus is on constructive guidance, ethical vigilance, and collaboration to ensure research quality, which is positive and hopeful for the scientific community and public health.
articles.personality_title: When reviewers spot possible mistakes in research, here’s how they can help
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
In cancer research, peer reviewers play a key role in checking the quality and honesty of scientific papers before they are published. Sometimes, reviewers notice things that look wrong or copied, which can be a tricky situation since mistakes can happen by accident, but serious misconduct can harm trust and patient safety.

**What happened**
A cancer researcher reviewing a paper saw that some images looked exactly like ones from another study. They were unsure whether it was a mistake or something worse. The article in Nature explains how reviewers can carefully raise concerns without making harsh accusations, protecting both science and people’s careers.

**Impact**
By encouraging reviewers to be watchful and to communicate respectfully, the process helps keep cancer research honest and reliable. This strengthens medical advances and protects patients who depend on trustworthy studies.

**What's next step**
Reviewers should report their concerns confidentially to journal editors, who can investigate carefully. This approach balances caution with integrity, making sure problems are addressed while avoiding unnecessary damage.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Reviewers who spot possible issues in research can help maintain trust in science by raising concerns thoughtfully and working with editors to ensure quality.
articles.personality_title_fr: Quand les évaluateurs repèrent des erreurs possibles dans la recherche, voici comment ils peuvent aider
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Dans la recherche sur le cancer, les évaluateurs jouent un rôle clé pour vérifier la qualité et l’honnêteté des articles scientifiques avant leur publication. Parfois, ils remarquent des éléments suspects ou copiés, ce qui est délicat car les erreurs peuvent être accidentelles, mais les fautes graves peuvent nuire à la confiance et à la sécurité des patients.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Un chercheur en cancérologie qui évaluait un article a vu que certaines images semblaient identiques à celles d’une autre étude. Il ne savait pas si c’était une erreur ou quelque chose de plus grave. L’article dans Nature explique comment les évaluateurs peuvent soulever des doutes avec prudence, protégeant ainsi la science et les carrières.

**Impact**
Encourager les évaluateurs à être vigilants et à communiquer respectueusement aide à maintenir la recherche sur le cancer honnête et fiable. Cela renforce les progrès médicaux et protège les patients qui comptent sur des études fiables.

**Quelle est la prochaine étape**
Les évaluateurs doivent signaler leurs préoccupations en toute confidentialité aux éditeurs de revues, qui peuvent enquêter attentivement. Cette méthode assure un équilibre entre prudence et intégrité, pour régler les problèmes sans causer de tort inutile.

**Une phrase à retenir**
Les évaluateurs qui détectent des problèmes possibles dans la recherche peuvent aider à préserver la confiance dans la science en soulevant leurs doutes avec soin et en collaborant avec les éditeurs pour garantir la qualité.
articles.personality_title_es: Cuando los revisores detectan posibles errores en la investigación, así pueden ayudar
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
En la investigación del cáncer, los revisores juegan un papel clave para verificar la calidad y honestidad de los artículos científicos antes de su publicación. A veces, notan cosas que parecen estar mal o copiadas, lo cual es delicado porque los errores pueden ser accidentales, pero las faltas graves dañan la confianza y la seguridad de los pacientes.

**Qué pasó**
Un investigador en cáncer que revisaba un artículo vio que algunas imágenes parecían idénticas a las de otro estudio. No estaba seguro si era un error o algo peor. El artículo en Nature explica cómo los revisores pueden plantear dudas con cuidado, protegiendo así la ciencia y las carreras.

**Impacto**
Al fomentar que los revisores estén atentos y comuniquen con respeto, se ayuda a mantener la investigación en cáncer honesta y confiable. Esto fortalece los avances médicos y protege a los pacientes que dependen de estudios confiables.

**Próximo paso**
Los revisores deben informar sus preocupaciones de forma confidencial a los editores de las revistas, quienes pueden investigar con cuidado. Este método equilibra la precaución con la integridad, asegurando que los problemas se resuelvan sin causar daño innecesario.

**Mensaje en una frase**
Los revisores que detectan posibles problemas en la investigación pueden ayudar a mantener la confianza en la ciencia al expresar sus dudas cuidadosamente y trabajar con los editores para garantizar la calidad.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm drawing of a vintage wooden desk scattered with carefully arranged scientific papers and open journals, featuring softly glowing microscope slides with faint overlapping cell images, alongside a thoughtful, gently illuminated magnifying glass resting near a sealed envelope symbolizing confidential communication, all rendered in soft, natural earth tones and muted blues.
